name: Ganesha Stavah
sanskrit: ajaM nirvikalpaM nirAkAramEkaM nirAnanda mAnanda madvaitapUrNaM paraM nirguNaM nirvishEShaM nirIhaM parabrahmarUpaM gaNEshaM bhajEma
meaning: Let us worship Ganesha who is the form of Parabrahman — unborn, beyond thought, formless, one, beyond joy yet full of non-dual bliss, supreme, beyond qualities, beyond distinction, desireless.
source: Ganpati Upanishad / Ganesha Stavam by Adi Shankaracharya

deepMeaning.symbolism: Ganesha is not just an elephant-headed deity but the Supreme Reality (Parabrahman) itself — formless, infinite, and beyond all attributes

keyTerms.ajam: Unborn - He was never born and will never die

deepMeaning.refrain: Each verse ends with 'parabrahmarUpaM gaNEshaM bhajEma' - Let us worship Ganesha who is the form of Parabrahman
deepMeaning.verse3theme: Verse 3 describes Ganesha as jagatkAraNam - the cause of the entire universe, worshipped by all gods and the whole world

trivia: This is an Advaita Vedanta hymn — it describes Ganesha not in physical form but as the formless Supreme Reality

name: Saraswati Vandana
sanskrit: Yā kundendu tuṣhāra hāra dhavalā yā śhubhra vastrāvṛtā Yā vīṇā vara daṇḍa maṇḍita karā yā śhveta padmāsanā Yā brahmāchyuta śhaṅkara prabhṛtibhir devaiḥ sadā vanditā Sā māṁ pātu Sarasvatī Bhagavatī nisḥśheṣa jāḍyāpahā
sanskritParts: Yā kundendu tuṣhāra hāra dhavalā yā śhubhra vastrāvṛtā
Yā vīṇā vara daṇḍa maṇḍita karā yā śhveta padmāsanā
Yā brahmāchyuta śhaṅkara prabhṛtibhir devaiḥ sadā vanditā
Sā māṁ pātu Sarasvatī Bhagavatī nisḥśheṣa jāḍyāpahā
meaning: She who is as white as jasmine, moon, snow, and pearl necklace, who wears pure white garments, whose hands are adorned with the veena, who sits on a white lotus, who is always worshipped by Brahma, Vishnu (Achyuta), Shiva (Shankara) and other gods — may that Saraswati Bhagavati, the remover of all ignorance and dullness, protect me.
occasion: Before study / Saraswati Puja / Vasant Panchami

deepMeaning.symbolism: Every aspect of Saraswati is white — representing purity of knowledge, untainted by worldly desires

appearance.color: White as jasmine (kunda), moon (indu), snow (tushara), and pearl necklace (hara)
appearance.hands: Adorned with the veena (stringed instrument of learning)

deepMeaning.worshippers: Even the Trinity — Brahma (creator), Achyuta/Vishnu (preserver), and Shankara/Shiva (destroyer) — worship her
deepMeaning.blessing: Nishshesha jadyapaha — complete remover of all ignorance and mental dullness

trivia: This shloka is recited across India before exams and at the start of educational events

name: Mantra Pushpam
sanskrit: yō-'pā-mpuṣpaṃ vēda Puṣpavān prajāvān paśumān bhavati chandramā vā apāmpuṣpam Puṣpavān prajāvān paśumān bhavati ya ēvaṃ vēda Yō-'pām āyatanaṃ vēda Āyatanavān bhavati
meaning: He who knows the flower of water becomes endowed with flowers, progeny, and cattle. The moon is the flower of water. He who knows the support (ayatanam) of water becomes established. The hymn then traces water's connection to fire, wind, sun, moon, stars, rain, and the year.
occasion: End of puja / Offering of mantras to deity

deepMeaning.symbolism: Water is the foundation of all life — the hymn traces cosmic connections showing how everything in nature is interconnected through water

connections.water_flower: Moon (Chandrama) is the flower of water
connections.water_fire: Fire (Agni) is the support of water, and water is the support of fire
connections.water_wind: Wind (Vayu) is the support of water
connections.water_sun: The Sun is the support of water
connections.water_moon: Moon is the support of water
connections.water_stars: Stars (Nakshatra) are the support of water
connections.water_rain: Rain (Parjanya) is the support of water
connections.water_year: The Year (Samvatsara) is the support of water

deepMeaning.refrain: Each section ends with 'Āyatanavān bhavati' — one becomes established/supported
deepMeaning.conclusion: Ends with a prayer to the King of Kings (Rajadhiraja) and Kubera

trivia: Mantra Pushpam is chanted at the end of all Vedic pujas while offering flowers — the mantras themselves become the flowers offered to God

name: Shanti Mantra (Bhadram Karnebhih)
sanskrit: Om Bhadram karnebhih Shrnnuyaama Devaah Bhadram Pashye maAkssabhir-Yajatraah Sthirai Ranggai stussttuva(g)um sastanuubhih Vyashema Deva hitam Yad-Aayuh Svasti Na Indro Vruddha-Shravaah Svasti Nah Puushaa Vishva-Vedaah Svasti Nah-staarkshyo Arissta-Nemih Svasti No Brihaspatir-Dadhaatu Om Shaantih Shaantih Shaantih
meaning: O Gods, may we hear auspicious things with our ears. O worshipful ones, may we see auspicious things with our eyes. May we live our full lifespan allotted by the gods with strong limbs and healthy bodies. May Indra of great fame bless us. May Pusha, the all-knowing, bless us. May Tarkshya (Garuda) of unobstructed path bless us. May Brihaspati grant us well-being. Om Peace, Peace, Peace.
occasion: Beginning and end of Vedic study / Puja

deepMeaning.symbolism: Prays for the proper functioning of all senses and a full, healthy life in service of the divine

prayers.ears: Bhadram karnebhih — May we hear only good/auspicious things
prayers.eyes: Bhadram pashyema — May we see only good/auspicious things
prayers.life: Vyashema deva hitam yad-aayuh — May we live the full divine lifespan

fourDeities.Indra: King of gods, of great fame (Vruddha-Shravah)
fourDeities.Brihaspati: Guru of the gods, teacher of wisdom

deepMeaning.svasti: Svasti means well-being/blessings — asked from four different deities

trivia: This is one of the most widely used shanti mantras, chanted at the beginning and end of Vedic recitations

name: Mahalakshmi Ashtakam
sanskrit: namastē'stu mahāmāyē śrīpīṭhē surapūjitē śaṅkhachakra gadāhastē mahālakṣmi namō'stu tē
sanskritParts: sarvaduḥkha harē dēvi mahālakṣmi namō'stu tē
siddhi buddhi pradē dēvi bhukti mukti pradāyini
mantra mūrtē sadā dēvi mahālakṣmi namō'stu tē
meaning: Salutations to Mahalakshmi — the great Mahamaya worshipped by gods, who holds conch, disc and mace; who rides Garuda and terrified the demon Kolasura; the all-knowing, boon-granting, destroyer of evil and sorrow; giver of success, wisdom, worldly enjoyment and liberation; seated on lotus, form of Parabrahman, supreme goddess, mother of the universe; dressed in white, adorned with ornaments, sustainer of the world.

deepMeaning.symbolism: Mahalakshmi is not just the goddess of wealth — she is the Supreme Mother, the form of Parabrahman, who gives both worldly enjoyment (bhukti) and spiritual liberation (mukti)

eightVerses.verse1: Mahamaya, worshipped by gods, holding conch, disc, and mace
eightVerses.verse2: Rides Garuda, terrified demon Kolasura, remover of all sins
eightVerses.verse3: All-knowing, all-granting, terrifying to evil, remover of all sorrows
eightVerses.verse4: Giver of success (siddhi) and wisdom (buddhi), worldly joy and liberation
eightVerses.verse5: Without beginning or end, primordial energy (Adi Shakti), supreme goddess
eightVerses.verse6: Gross and subtle, fierce power, great remover of sins
eightVerses.verse7: Seated on lotus, form of Parabrahman, supreme goddess, mother of universe
eightVerses.verse8: Dressed in white, adorned with ornaments, sustainer and mother of the world

phalaShruti.once: Reading once daily destroys great sins (mahapapa vinashanam)
phalaShruti.twice: Reading twice daily gives wealth and grain (dhana dhanya samanvitah)
phalaShruti.thrice: Reading thrice daily destroys great enemies (mahashatru vinashanam)

trivia: Ashtakam means 'eight verses' — this is one of the most popular Lakshmi stotras, attributed to Indra who composed it to please Lakshmi
